name: ctfd
description: The CTFd provider for Pulumi, to manage its resources as code.
attribution: This Pulumi package is based on the [`ctfd` Terraform Provider](https://github.com/ctfer-io/terraform-provider-ctfd).

nodejs.packageDescription: The CTFd provider for Pulumi, to manage its resources as code.
nodejs.readme:
> This provider is a derived work of the [Terraform Provider](https://github.com/ctfer-io/terraform-provider-ctfd)
> distributed under [MPL 2.0](https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/MPL/2.0/). If you encounter a bug or missing feature,
> first check the [`pulumi-ctfd` repo](https://github.com/ctfer-io/pulumi-ctfd/issues); however, if that doesn't turn up anything,
> please consult the source [`terraform-provider-ctfd` repo](https://github.com/ctfer-io/terraform-provider-ctfd/issues).

python.readme:
> This provider is a derived work of the [Terraform Provider](https://github.com/ctfer-io/terraform-provider-ctfd)
> distributed under [MPL 2.0](https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/MPL/2.0/). If you encounter a bug or missing feature,
> first check the [`pulumi-ctfd` repo](https://github.com/ctfer-io/pulumi-ctfd/issues); however, if that doesn't turn up anything,
> please consult the source [`terraform-provider-ctfd` repo](https://github.com/ctfer-io/terraform-provider-ctfd/issues).

apiKey.description:
User API key. Could use `CTFD_API_KEY` environment variable instead. Despite being the most convenient way to
authenticate yourself, we do not recommend it as you will probably generate a long-live token without any rotation
policy.

nonce.description: User session nonce, comes with session. Could use `CTFD_NONCE` environment variable instead.

session.description: User session token, comes with nonce. Could use `CTFD_SESSION` environment variable instead.

url.description: CTFd base URL (e.g. `https://my-ctf.lan`). Could use `CTFD_URL` environment variable instead.

content.description: Raw content of the file, perfectly fit the use-cases of a .txt document or anything with a simple binary content. You could provide it from the file-system using `file("${path.module}/...")`.

contentb64.description: Base 64 content of the file, perfectly fit the use-cases of complex binaries. You could provide it from the file-system using `filebase64("${path.module}/...")`.

id.description: Identifier of the file, used internally to handle the CTFd corresponding object.

location.description: Location where the file is stored on the CTFd instance, for download purposes.

name.description: Name of the file as displayed to end-users.

sha1sum.description: The sha1 sum of the file.

content.description: The actual flag to match. Consider using the convention `MYCTF{value}` with `MYCTF` being the shortcode of your event's name and `value` depending on each challenge.

data.description: The flag sensitivity information, either case*sensitive or case*insensitive

id.description: Identifier of the flag, used internally to handle the CTFd corresponding object.

type.description: The type of the flag, could be either static or regex

content.description: Content of the hint as displayed to the end-user.

cost.description: Cost of the hint, and if any specified, the end-user will consume its own (or team) points to get it.

id.description: Identifier of the hint, used internally to handle the CTFd corresponding object.

requirements.description: Other hints required to be consumed before getting this one. Useful for cost-increasing hint strategies with more and more help.

behavior.description: Behavior if not unlocked, either hidden or anonymized.

category.description: Category of the challenge that CTFd groups by on the web UI.

connectionInfo.description: Connection Information to connect to the challenge instance, useful for pwn or web pentest.

description.description: Description of the challenge, consider using multiline descriptions for better style.

files.description: List of files given to players to flag the challenge.

flags.description: List of challenge flags that solves it.

function.description: Decay function to define how the challenge value evolve through solves, either linear or logarithmic.

hints.description: List of hints about the challenge displayed to the end-user.

maxAttempts.description: Maximum amount of attempts before being unable to flag the challenge.

name.description: Name of the challenge, displayed as it.

next.description: Suggestion for the end-user as next challenge to work on.

requirements.description: List of required challenges that needs to get flagged before this one being accessible. Useful for skill-trees-like strategy CTF.

state.description: State of the challenge, either hidden or visible.

tags.description: List of challenge tags that will be displayed to the end-user. You could use them to give some quick insights of what a challenge involves.

topics.description: List of challenge topics that are displayed to the administrators for maintenance and planification.

type.description: Type of the challenge defining its layout, either standard or dynamic.

behavior.description: Behavior if not unlocked, either hidden or anonymized.

provider.description:
The provider type for the ctfd package. By default, resources use package-wide configuration
settings, however an explicit `Provider` instance may be created and passed during resource
construction to achieve fine-grained programmatic control over provider settings. See the
[documentation](https://www.pulumi.com/docs/reference/programming-model/#providers) for more information.

apiKey.description:
User API key. Could use `CTFD_API_KEY` environment variable instead. Despite being the most convenient way to
authenticate yourself, we do not recommend it as you will probably generate a long-live token without any rotation
policy.

nonce.description: User session nonce, comes with session. Could use `CTFD_NONCE` environment variable instead.

session.description: User session token, comes with nonce. Could use `CTFD_SESSION` environment variable instead.

url.description: CTFd base URL (e.g. `https://my-ctf.lan`). Could use `CTFD_URL` environment variable instead.

apiKey.description:
User API key. Could use `CTFD_API_KEY` environment variable instead. Despite being the most convenient way to
authenticate yourself, we do not recommend it as you will probably generate a long-live token without any rotation
policy.

nonce.description: User session nonce, comes with session. Could use `CTFD_NONCE` environment variable instead.

session.description: User session token, comes with nonce. Could use `CTFD_SESSION` environment variable instead.

url.description: CTFd base URL (e.g. `https://my-ctf.lan`). Could use `CTFD_URL` environment variable instead.

category.description: Category of the challenge that CTFd groups by on the web UI.

connectionInfo.description: Connection Information to connect to the challenge instance, useful for pwn, web and infrastructure pentests.

decay.description: The decay defines from each number of solves does the decay function triggers until reaching minimum. This function is defined by CTFd and could be configured through `.function`.

description.description: Description of the challenge, consider using multiline descriptions for better style.

files.description: List of files given to players to flag the challenge.

flags.description: List of challenge flags that solves it.

function.description: Decay function to define how the challenge value evolve through solves, either linear or logarithmic.

hints.description: List of hints about the challenge displayed to the end-user.

maxAttempts.description: Maximum amount of attempts before being unable to flag the challenge.

minimum.description: The minimum points for a dynamic-score challenge to reach with the decay function. Once there, no solve could have more value.

name.description: Name of the file as displayed to end-users.

next.description: Suggestion for the end-user as next challenge to work on.

requirements.description: Other hints required to be consumed before getting this one. Useful for cost-increasing hint strategies with more and more help.

state.description: State of the challenge, either hidden or visible.

tags.description: List of challenge tags that will be displayed to the end-user. You could use them to give some quick insights of what a challenge involves.

topics.description: List of challenge topics that are displayed to the administrators for maintenance and planification.

type.description: The type of the flag, could be either static or regex

value.description: The value (points) of the challenge once solved. Internally, the provider will handle what target is legitimate depending on the `.type` value, i.e. either `value` for "standard" or `initial` for "dynamic".

category.description: Category of the challenge that CTFd groups by on the web UI.

value.description: The value (points) of the challenge once solved. Internally, the provider will handle what target is legitimate depending on the `.type` value, i.e. either `value` for "standard" or `initial` for "dynamic".

value.description: The value (points) of the challenge once solved. Internally, the provider will handle what target is legitimate depending on the `.type` value, i.e. either `value` for "standard" or `initial` for "dynamic".

affiliation.description: Affiliation to a company or agency.

banned.description: Is true if the team is banned from the CTF.

captain.description: Member who is captain of the team. Must be part of the members too. Note it could cause a fatal error in case of resource import with an inconsistent CTFd configuration i.e. if a team has no captain yet (should not be possible).

country.description: Country the team represent or is hail from.

hidden.description: Is true if the team is hidden to the participants.

members.description: List of members (User), defined by their IDs.

password.description: Password of the team. Notice that during a CTF you may not want to update those to avoid defaulting team accesses.

website.description: Website, blog, or anything similar (displayed to other participants).

banned.description: Is true if the user is banned from the CTF.

country.description: Country the user represent or is native from.

email.description: Email of the user, may be used to verify the account.

hidden.description: Is true if the user is hidden to the participants.

language.description: Language the user is fluent in.

name.description: Name or pseudo of the user.

password.description: Password of the user. Notice than during a CTF you may not want to update those to avoid defaulting user accesses.

verified.description: Is true if the user has verified its account by email, or if set by an admin.
